label: GitHub API
description: Tools that enable LLMs to interact directly with the GitHub API.

tools.name: AcceptGithubRepoInvitation
tools.description:
Accept a GitHub repository invitation.

This tool accepts an invitation to join a GitHub repository for the authenticated user. Use it when you need to confirm participation in a repo after receiving an invitation.

parameters.name: invitation_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier for the GitHub invitation to be accepted.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: AddAppAccessRestrictions
tools.description:
Grant specified apps push access to a protected branch.

    Use this tool to grant specific GitHub Apps push access to protected branches in repositories. Apps must have 'write' access to 'contents' to be authorized.

    Note: Understanding the request schema is necessary to properly create
    the stringified JSON input object for execution.

This operation also requires path parameters.

    Modes:
    - GET_REQUEST_SCHEMA: Returns the schema. Only call if you don't
      already have it. Do NOT call repeatedly if you already received
      the schema.
    - EXECUTE: Performs the operation with the provided request body
      JSON.
      Note: You must also provide the required path parameters when executing.

    If you need the schema, call with mode='get_request_schema' ONCE, then execute.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Operation mode: 'get_request_schema' returns the OpenAPI spec for the request body, 'execute' performs the actual operation

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The repository account owner. The name is not case sensitive.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the repository. This is not case sensitive.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: branch_name
parameters.description: The name of the branch to grant push access. Cannot contain wildcard characters.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: request_body
parameters.description: Stringified JSON representing the request body. Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: AddCustomLabelsToRunner
tools.description:
Add custom labels to a self-hosted runner in an enterprise.

Use this tool to attach custom labels to a self-hosted runner within an enterprise on GitHub. Requires authentication with a token that has the `manage_runners:enterprise` scope.

parameters.name: custom_labels
parameters.description: An array of names for the custom labels to add to the self-hosted runner.

parameters.name: enterprise_identifier
parameters.description: The slug or ID of the enterprise for the self-hosted runner. It identifies the enterprise name or ID in GitHub.

parameters.name: runner_unique_id
parameters.description: The unique integer identifier for the self-hosted runner.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: AddEmailToGithubAccount
tools.description:
Add a new email to the authenticated GitHub user's account.

Use this tool to add an email address to the authenticated GitHub account of the user. This action requires user scope authentication.

Note: Understanding the request schema is necessary to properly create
the stringified JSON input object for execution.

Modes:
- GET_REQUEST_SCHEMA: Returns the schema. Only call if you don't
  already have it. Do NOT call repeatedly if you already received
  the schema.
- EXECUTE: Performs the operation with the provided request body
  JSON.

If you need the schema, call with mode='get_request_schema' ONCE, then execute.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Operation mode: 'get_request_schema' returns the OpenAPI spec for the request body, 'execute' performs the actual operation

parameters.name: request_body
parameters.description: Stringified JSON representing the request body. Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: AddGithubAuthorizedSshKey
tools.description:
Add an authorized SSH key to GitHub Enterprise.

This tool adds an authorized SSH key to a GitHub Enterprise account. It is useful when you want to securely access your GitHub repositories using SSH. Make sure to provide the SSH key in the required format.

parameters.name: public_ssh_key
parameters.description: The public SSH key to add to GitHub Enterprise. Ensure it is in the correct format.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: AddGithubReleaseReaction
tools.description:
Add a reaction to a GitHub release.

Use this tool to create a reaction to a specific release on GitHub. If a reaction already exists, it will return a confirmation with status 200 OK.

parameters.name: reaction_type
parameters.description: The reaction type for the release, e.g., '+1', 'laugh', 'heart'. Choose from '+1', 'laugh', 'heart', 'hooray', 'rocket', 'eyes'.

parameters.name: release_identifier
parameters.description: The unique identifier for the GitHub release to which the reaction will be added.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the repository. It is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository on GitHub. The name is not case sensitive.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: AddGpgKeyToGithub
tools.description:
Add a GPG key to your authenticated GitHub account.

This tool allows you to add a GPG key to your GitHub account after authenticating via Basic Auth or OAuth with the appropriate scope. Use it to enhance security by managing GPG keys on GitHub.

parameters.name: gpg_key_ascii_armored_format
parameters.description: A GPG key in ASCII-armored format to be added to your GitHub account.

parameters.name: new_gpg_key_name
parameters.description: A descriptive name for the new GPG key to be added to your GitHub account.

gpg_key_ascii_armored_format.value:
-----BEGIN PGP PUBLIC KEY BLOCK-----
Version: OpenPGP.js v4.10.10

mQENBFwH+IIOAwCAy2bypA3x...XYZ
-----END PGP PUBLIC KEY BLOCK-----

tools.name: AddLabelsToGithubIssue
tools.description:
Add labels to a GitHub issue to categorize it.

    Use this tool to apply one or more labels to a specific issue in a GitHub repository. It helps in categorizing and organizing issues for better project management.

    Note: Understanding the request schema is necessary to properly create
    the stringified JSON input object for execution.

This operation also requires path parameters.

    Modes:
    - GET_REQUEST_SCHEMA: Returns the schema. Only call if you don't
      already have it. Do NOT call repeatedly if you already received
      the schema.
    - EXECUTE: Performs the operation with the provided request body
      JSON.
      Note: You must also provide the required path parameters when executing.

    If you need the schema, call with mode='get_request_schema' ONCE, then execute.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Operation mode: 'get_request_schema' returns the OpenAPI spec for the request body, 'execute' performs the actual operation

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The GitHub account owner of the repository. This value is not case sensitive.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the GitHub repository where the issue exists. It is not case sensitive.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: issue_number
parameters.description: The numeric identifier of the issue to which labels will be added.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: request_body
parameters.description: Stringified JSON representing the request body. Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: AddLabelsToRunner
tools.description:
Add custom labels to a self-hosted runner in an organization.

This tool adds custom labels to a self-hosted GitHub Actions runner configured in an organization. Use this tool when you need to organize or categorize runners with specific labels. Requires authentication with an access token having the `admin:org` scope.

parameters.name: custom_labels_to_add
parameters.description: An array of strings representing the custom labels to add to the self-hosted runner. Each label is a string.

parameters.name: organization_name
parameters.description: The name of the GitHub organization. It is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: runner_id
parameters.description: Unique identifier of the self-hosted runner to which labels are added.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: AddOrgAccessToRunnerGroup
tools.description:
Add organization access to a self-hosted runner group in an enterprise.

Use this tool to add an organization to a selected list that can access a self-hosted runner group. The runner group's visibility must be set to 'selected'. Requires an access token with 'manage_runners:enterprise' scope.

parameters.name: enterprise_identifier
parameters.description: The slug or ID of the enterprise. Use either the enterprise name slug or its ID.

parameters.name: organization_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the organization to add access to the self-hosted runner group.

parameters.name: runner_group_id
parameters.description: Unique identifier for the self-hosted runner group. Required for adding organization access to it.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: AddOrUpdateGithubCollaborator
tools.description:
Add or update a collaborator on a GitHub repository.

Use this tool to add a new collaborator or update the permission level of an existing collaborator on a GitHub repository. The invitee will receive a notification, and changes are instantly applied. Be aware of rate limits and permissions restrictions.

parameters.name: github_user_handle
parameters.description: The GitHub user handle for the collaborator to be added or updated.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the GitHub repository. This input is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The GitHub username of the account owner of the repository. This is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: permission_level_for_github_collaborator
parameters.description: Specify the permission to grant or update for a collaborator on an organization-owned GitHub repository. Only valid for such repositories.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: AddOrUpdateGithubTeamProjectPermissions
tools.description:
Add or update a GitHub team's permissions on an organization project.

Use this tool to add a project to a GitHub team or update a team's permissions on a project within the same organization. The user must have admin permissions for the project.

parameters.name: organization_name
parameters.description: The GitHub organization name. This is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: project_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the project to update or add to the team.

parameters.name: team_slug
parameters.description: The slug representation of the GitHub team's name within the organization. This is used to identify the team in the request.

parameters.name: project_permission_level
parameters.description: Permission level to grant the team for the project. Options: 'read', 'write', 'admin'. Default uses the team's current level.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: AddProjectCollaborator
tools.description:
Add a collaborator to an organization project.

This tool adds a collaborator to a specified organization project and assigns a permission level. It requires the user to be an organization owner or a project admin.

parameters.name: collaborator_username
parameters.description: The GitHub username of the collaborator to be added to the project.

parameters.name: project_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the project to which a collaborator is being added. This ID is required to specify the exact project for collaboration.

parameters.name: collaborator_permission_level
parameters.description: The permission level to assign to the collaborator. Options are: 'read', 'write', or 'admin'.

tools.name: AddReactionToCommitComment
tools.description:
Add a reaction to a GitHub commit comment.

Use this tool to add a reaction (like, love, etc.) to a comment on a GitHub commit. It confirms if the reaction was already added with an HTTP `200` status.

parameters.name: comment_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the GitHub commit comment to which the reaction will be added.

parameters.name: reaction_type
parameters.description: The type of reaction to add to the commit comment, e.g., '+1', 'heart', 'laugh'.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the GitHub repository. It is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The GitHub username of the repository owner. This value is case-insensitive.

tools.name: AddReactionToGithubComment
tools.description:
Add a reaction to a GitHub issue comment.

Use this tool to add a specific reaction to a comment on a GitHub issue. It checks if the reaction type has already been added, returning an HTTP `200` status in that case.

parameters.name: comment_unique_identifier
parameters.description: The unique identifier for the GitHub comment to which a reaction is being added.

parameters.name: reaction_type
parameters.description: The type of reaction to add to the issue comment. Valid options: '+1', '-1', 'laugh', 'confused', 'heart', 'hooray', 'rocket', 'eyes'.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the GitHub repository. This name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

tools.name: AddReactionToGithubIssue
tools.description:
Add a reaction to a GitHub issue.

Use this tool to add a specific reaction to a GitHub issue. If a reaction has already been added by the user, a response with HTTP status 200 will confirm this. Suitable for managing issue reactions on GitHub repositories.

parameters.name: github_issue_number
parameters.description: The number that uniquely identifies the issue on GitHub.

parameters.name: reaction_type_to_add
parameters.description: The reaction type to add to the issue. Options include '+1', '-1', 'laugh', 'confused', 'heart', 'hooray', 'rocket', 'eyes'.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the GitHub repository. This is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The GitHub account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

tools.name: AddReactionToGithubTeamDiscussion
tools.description:
Add a reaction to a GitHub team discussion.

Use this tool to add a specific reaction emoji to a team discussion in a GitHub organization. It requires OAuth access tokens with the `write:discussion` scope. This is useful for engaging with team discussions directly through the API.

parameters.description: The unique identifier number for the team discussion.

parameters.name: organization_name
parameters.description: The name of the GitHub organization. It is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: reaction_type
parameters.description: The reaction type to add to the team discussion. Valid options include: '+1', '-1', 'laugh', 'confused', 'heart', 'hooray', 'rocket', 'eyes'.

parameters.name: team_slug
parameters.description: The URL-friendly version of the team's name.

tools.name: AddReactionToPrComment
tools.description:
Adds a reaction to a pull request review comment on GitHub.

Use this tool to add a reaction to a specific pull request review comment on GitHub. This can be helpful for acknowledging comments or expressing opinions quickly. A successful addition results in an HTTP `200` status.

parameters.name: comment_unique_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the pull request review comment.

parameters.name: reaction_type_for_pr_comment
parameters.description: Specifies the type of reaction to add to the pull request review comment. Valid options are '+1', '-1', 'laugh', 'confused', 'heart', 'hooray', 'rocket', 'eyes'.

parameters.name: repository_owner

tools.name: AddReactionToTeamDiscussionComment
tools.description:
Add a reaction to a GitHub team discussion comment.

Use this tool to add a reaction emoji to a specific GitHub team discussion comment within an organization. Useful for engaging with team discussions or acknowledging comments. Requires appropriate OAuth scope.

parameters.description: The unique number identifying the team discussion comment to react to.

parameters.name: organization_name
parameters.description: The name of the organization. This value is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: team_slug
parameters.description: The slug of the team name within the organization, used to identify the team.

Add repository access to a self-hosted runner group.

This tool is used to add a repository to the list of selected repositories that can access a self-hosted runner group within an organization. parameters.name: repository_unique_id

Add a repository to a GitHub installation for the authenticated user.

tools.name: AddRepositoryToSecret
tools.description:
Add a repository to a GitHub organization secret.

tools.name: AddRepoToOrgSecret

Add a repository to an organization's secret.

This tool adds a specified repository to an organization secret with 'selected' visibility. It requires authentication with an access token having 'admin:org' scope. GitHub Apps need 'secrets' organization permission.

parameters.description: The organization's name. It is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_id
parameters.description: The unique integer ID of the repository to be added to the organization secret. This ID specifies which repository you want to include.

parameters.name: secret_name
parameters.description: The name of the organization secret to which the repository will be added.

tools.name: AddRepoToOrgVariable

Add a repository to an organization's selected variables.

Use this tool to add a repository to a specific organization variable that is available to selected repositories on GitHub. This requires an access token with `admin:org` scope or GitHub App permission `organization_actions_variables:write`. The repository and organization must have the `visibility` field set to `selected`.

parameters.name: organization_name
parameters.description: The name of the organization. This is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_id
parameters.description: The integer ID of the repository to be added to the organization variable. This is a required field.

parameters.name: variable_name
parameters.description: The name of the organization variable to which the repository will be added.

tools.name: AddRepoToRequiredWorkflow

Adds a repository to a GitHub required workflow.

tools.name: AddStatusCheckContextsToBranch
tools.description:
Add status check contexts to a protected branch.

    This tool allows users to add status check contexts to a specified protected branch in a GitHub repository. It should be called when managing branch protection rules and ensuring specific contexts are required for status checks.

    Note: Understanding the request schema is necessary to properly create
    the stringified JSON input object for execution.

This operation also requires path parameters.

    Modes:
    - GET_REQUEST_SCHEMA: Returns the schema. Only call if you don't
      already have it. Do NOT call repeatedly if you already received
      the schema.
    - EXECUTE: Performs the operation with the provided request body
      JSON.
      Note: You must also provide the required path parameters when executing.

    If you need the schema, call with mode='get_request_schema' ONCE, then execute.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Operation mode: 'get_request_schema' returns the OpenAPI spec for the request body, 'execute' performs the actual operation

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the repository to add status check contexts to. This is not case sensitive.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: branch_name
parameters.description: The name of the branch to add status check contexts to. Cannot contain wildcard characters. Use GraphQL API for wildcards.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: request_body
parameters.description: Stringified JSON representing the request body. Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'

Add or update a user's membership in a GitHub team.

This tool adds a member to a GitHub organization's team or updates their role if they are already a member. It is used by authenticated organization owners or team maintainers. If the person isn't part of the organization, an invitation is sent, and their membership will be pending until accepted.

tools.name: CancelGithubWorkflowRun

Cancels a GitHub workflow run using its ID.

Use this tool to cancel an ongoing GitHub Actions workflow run. Authentication with an access token having `repo` scope is required. Useful for stopping workflows that may be executing erroneously or need interruption.

parameters.description: The name of the repository. This is not case sensitive and should match the repository where the workflow run is located.

parameters.name: repository_owner

tools.name: DeleteUserEmail
tools.description:
Delete an email for the authenticated GitHub user.

Use this tool to delete an email address associated with the authenticated user's GitHub account. This action requires user authentication and appropriate permissions.

Note: Understanding the request schema is necessary to properly create
the stringified JSON input object for execution.

Modes:
- GET_REQUEST_SCHEMA: Returns the schema. Only call if you don't
  already have it. Do NOT call repeatedly if you already received
  the schema.
- EXECUTE: Performs the operation with the provided request body
  JSON.

If you need the schema, call with mode='get_request_schema' ONCE, then execute.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Operation mode: 'get_request_schema' returns the OpenAPI spec for the request body, 'execute' performs the actual operation

parameters.name: request_body
parameters.description: Stringified JSON representing the request body. Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'

tools.name: GithubManageEnvironment
tools.description:
Create or update a GitHub environment with protection rules.

    Use this tool to create or update a GitHub environment, applying protection rules like required reviewers. Ensure you authenticate with an access token with the `repo` scope. GitHub Apps need `administration:write` permission for the repository.

    Note: Understanding the request schema is necessary to properly create
    the stringified JSON input object for execution.

This operation also requires path parameters.

    Modes:
    - GET_REQUEST_SCHEMA: Returns the schema. Only call if you don't
      already have it. Do NOT call repeatedly if you already received
      the schema.
    - EXECUTE: Performs the operation with the provided request body
      JSON.
      Note: You must also provide the required path parameters when executing.

    If you need the schema, call with mode='get_request_schema' ONCE, then execute.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Operation mode: 'get_request_schema' returns the OpenAPI spec for the request body, 'execute' performs the actual operation

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the GitHub repository. This value is not case sensitive.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: environment_name
parameters.description: The name of the GitHub environment to create or update. This should be a string that accurately identifies the environment within the repository.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: request_body
parameters.description: Stringified JSON representing the request body. Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'

tools.name: ListGithubIssues
tools.description:
Get issues assigned to you across all GitHub repositories.

This tool retrieves a list of issues that are assigned to the authenticated user from all visible repositories on GitHub, including owned, member, and organization repositories. It can be used to monitor workload and track tasks across projects. Note that the results may include pull requests as well, identified by a `pull_request` key.

parameters.name: include_collaborative_repositories
parameters.description: Include issues from collaborative repositories. Set to true to filter issues where you have collaborative access.

parameters.name: include_owned_repositories
parameters.description: Set to true to include issues from repositories owned by the authenticated user.

parameters.name: include_pull_requests
parameters.description: Set to true to include pull requests in the issues list.

parameters.name: issue_filter_type
parameters.description: Specifies the type of issues to return: assigned, created, mentioned, subscribed, repos, or all.

parameters.name: issue_labels
parameters.description: Comma-separated list of label names to filter issues. Example: 'bug,ui,@high'.

parameters.name: issue_state
parameters.description: Specifies the state of issues to retrieve: `open`, `closed`, or `all`.

parameters.name: organization_repositories
parameters.description: Include issues from organization repositories when set to true. If false, include issues from all repositories.

parameters.name: page_number
parameters.description: The specific page of results to fetch. Use this for pagination to navigate through large list of issues.

parameters.name: results_per_page
parameters.description: The number of results per page, maximum is 100.

parameters.name: sort_direction
parameters.description: Specifies the order of sorting for the results. Use 'asc' for ascending and 'desc' for descending.

parameters.name: sort_issues_by
parameters.description: Specify the criteria to sort issues by: 'created', 'updated', or 'comments'.

parameters.name: updated_since_timestamp
parameters.description: Show issues updated after this timestamp in ISO 8601 format: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ.

Use this tool to retrieve a list of webhook deliveries for a specific webhook configured in a GitHub repository. It is useful for monitoring and debugging webhook events.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the GitHub repository (case insensitive).

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. Not case sensitive.

parameters.name: webhook_hook_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the webhook. This is necessary to fetch the specific webhook deliveries for the repository.

parameters.name: include_redelivered_events
parameters.description: Include redelivered webhook events in the results if set to true.

parameters.name: pagination_start_cursor
parameters.description: The starting point for fetching the page of deliveries. Use the `link` header for next/previous page cursors.

parameters.name: results_per_page
parameters.description: The maximum number of webhook delivery results to fetch per page, up to 100.

tools.name: ListGithubWorkflowJobs
tools.description:
Fetches jobs for a specific GitHub workflow run.

Use this tool to retrieve jobs associated with a GitHub workflow run. Requires read access to the repository. For private repositories, an access token with the `repo` scope is needed. GitHub Apps must have the `actions:read` permission. Parameters can be used to filter results.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the GitHub repository. This is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. It is not case sensitive and identifies whose account owns the repository.

parameters.name: workflow_run_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the GitHub workflow run to fetch jobs for.

parameters.name: job_filter_by_completion_time
parameters.description: Filter jobs by their `completed_at` timestamp. Use 'latest' for the most recent execution or 'all' for all executions.

parameters.name: results_page_number
parameters.description: Page number for paginated results to fetch from the workflow jobs list.

parameters.name: results_per_page
parameters.description: Specify the number of job results to return per page, with a maximum of 100.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: ListGithubWorkflowRuns
tools.description:
Retrieve all workflow runs for a GitHub repository.

This tool retrieves a list of all workflow runs for a specified GitHub repository. It can be used to track the status and history of workflows in the repository. Works with repositories you have read access to. For private repositories, an access token with the 'repo' scope is needed.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the GitHub repository (case insensitive).

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The GitHub username or organization name that owns the repository. It is case-insensitive.

parameters.name: actor_username
parameters.description: Specify the username of the user whose workflow runs you want to retrieve. Use the login of the user who initiated the run.

parameters.name: branch_name
parameters.description: Specify the branch name to filter workflow runs associated with that branch.

parameters.name: check_suite_id
parameters.description: Returns workflow runs with the specified check suite ID.

parameters.name: filter_by_head_sha
parameters.description: Only returns workflow runs associated with the specified commit SHA (head_sha).

parameters.name: omit_pull_requests
parameters.description: If true, pull requests are excluded from the workflow runs response.

parameters.name: results_page_number
parameters.description: Page number of the results to fetch, used for paginating results.

parameters.name: results_per_page
parameters.description: The number of results to return per page, with a maximum limit of 100.

parameters.name: triggering_event
parameters.description: Specify the event that triggers the workflow run, such as 'push', 'pull_request', or 'issue'.

parameters.name: workflow_created_date_range
parameters.description: Specify a date-time range to filter workflow runs by creation date. Use GitHub's specific date syntax for format.

parameters.name: workflow_run_status
parameters.description: Specifies the desired status or conclusion of the workflow runs to retrieve, such as 'success', 'in_progress', etc.

tools.name: ListOrgCodeScanningAlerts
tools.description:
Retrieve code scanning alerts for an organization's repositories.

This tool lists code scanning alerts for the default branch of all eligible repositories within a specified organization. It requires the user to be an owner or security manager of the organization, and access tokens with the necessary scopes (`repo`, `security_events`, or `public_repo` for public repositories).

parameters.name: organization_name
parameters.description: The name of the organization. This field is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: alert_severity
parameters.description: Specifies the severity of code scanning alerts to be returned. Acceptable values include 'critical', 'high', 'medium', 'low', 'warning', 'note', and 'error'.

parameters.name: alert_state
parameters.description: Filter code scanning alerts by their state: 'open', 'closed', 'dismissed', or 'fixed'.

parameters.name: code_scanning_tool_guid
parameters.description: The GUID of a specific code scanning tool. Use this to filter alerts by the tool. Must not use with `tool_name`.

parameters.name: cursor_before
parameters.description: A cursor used to fetch results occurring before this point in the data timeline.

parameters.name: filter_by_tool_name
parameters.description: Specify the name of a code scanning tool to filter results. Only alerts from this tool will be listed. Ensure not to use `tool_guid` if this is specified.

parameters.name: results_after_cursor
parameters.description: A cursor indicating the point after which to retrieve results. Used for pagination.

parameters.name: results_page_number
parameters.description: The page number of the results to fetch from the list of code scanning alerts.

parameters.name: results_per_page
parameters.description: The number of results per page, with a maximum limit of 100.

parameters.name: sort_direction
parameters.description: Specifies the sort order of the results. Use 'asc' for ascending or 'desc' for descending.

parameters.name: sort_results_by
parameters.description: Specifies the property by which to sort the results. Options are 'created' or 'updated'.

tools.name: ListOrgSecretScanningAlerts
tools.description:
Retrieve secret scanning alerts for an organization's repositories.

This tool provides a list of secret scanning alerts from eligible repositories within an organization, sorted from newest to oldest. It should be called by users who are administrators or security managers of the organization, using an appropriate access token. GitHub Apps with `secret_scanning_alerts` read permission can also utilize this endpoint.

parameters.name: organization_name
parameters.description: The name of the organization for which secret scanning alerts are to be listed. This value is not case-sensitive.

parameters.name: alert_resolution_filter
parameters.description: A comma-separated list of resolutions to filter secret scanning alerts. Valid options are `false_positive`, `wont_fix`, `revoked`, `pattern_edited`, `pattern_deleted`, and `used_in_tests`.

parameters.name: alert_state
parameters.description: Specify 'open' or 'resolved' to filter secret scanning alerts by their state.

parameters.name: results_page_number
parameters.description: The page number of results to retrieve, starting from 1. Determines which subset of results will be returned.

parameters.name: results_per_page
parameters.description: The number of results to return per page, with a maximum of 100.

parameters.name: search_after_cursor
parameters.description: A cursor for paginating results, provided in the Link header. Use an empty string for the initial request to receive a starting cursor.

parameters.name: search_before_cursor
parameters.description: A cursor indicating that the query should only look for events before this point. Use an empty string to get an initial cursor.

parameters.name: secret_types
parameters.description: Comma-separated list of secret types to return. Defaults to all secret types. Refer to the GitHub documentation for details on secret types.

parameters.name: sort_by_property
parameters.description: Choose 'created' to sort by alert creation date or 'updated' to sort by last update or resolution.

parameters.name: sort_direction
parameters.description: Specifies the order to sort the results: ascending ('asc') or descending ('desc').

Alerts are only available for organizations where the user has ownership or security management permissions.

parameters.name: enterprise_identifier
parameters.description: The slug or ID of the enterprise. This identifies the specific enterprise to list alerts for.

parameters.name: cursor_after
parameters.description: A cursor for retrieving results after this point, as specified in the Link header.

parameters.name: cursor_before
parameters.description: A cursor to fetch results before this point, as specified by the link header.

parameters.name: results_per_page
parameters.description: The number of results per page. Maximum is 100.

parameters.name: secret_types_to_return

parameters.name: sort_by
parameters.description: Specify 'created' to sort by alert creation date or 'updated' to sort by the last update or resolution date.

parameters.name: sort_direction
parameters.description: Specify the direction ('asc' or 'desc') to sort the secret scanning alerts results.

Retrieve repositories for a user's migration.

This tool lists all the repositories associated with a user's migration on GitHub. Use it when you need to access the repositories involved in a specific migration.

parameters.name: migration_unique_identifier
parameters.description: The unique identifier for the user migration to retrieve repositories.

parameters.name: result_page_number
parameters.description: Specify the page number of results to retrieve. Use this to paginate through multiple pages of repository data.

parameters.name: results_per_page
parameters.description: The number of repository results to return per page, with a maximum of 100.

tools.name: ListUserMigrations
tools.description:
Lists all migrations a user has started.

Use this tool to retrieve a list of all the migrations initiated by an authenticated user on GitHub.

parameters.name: results_page_number
parameters.description: The specific page of migration results to retrieve, starting from 1.

parameters.name: results_per_page
parameters.description: The number of migration results per page, with a maximum of 100.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: ListUserNotifications
tools.description:
Retrieve notifications for the authenticated GitHub user.

This tool retrieves all notifications for the authenticated GitHub user, sorted by most recently updated. It should be called when the user wants to check their latest notifications.

parameters.name: filter_notifications_before_date
parameters.description: Only show notifications updated before the specified ISO 8601 timestamp (`YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`).

parameters.name: include_read_notifications
parameters.description: Set to `true` to include notifications marked as read in the results.

parameters.name: notifications_since_timestamp
parameters.description: Return notifications updated after this timestamp in ISO 8601 format: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ.

parameters.name: only_show_participating_notifications
parameters.description: If true, only shows notifications where the user is directly participating or mentioned.

parameters.name: results_page_number
parameters.description: Specify the page number of the notification results to fetch.

parameters.name: results_per_page
parameters.description: The number of notifications to display per page, with a maximum limit of 50.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: ListUserOrganizations
tools.description:
List organizations for the authenticated GitHub user.

This tool retrieves a list of organizations that the authenticated user can interact with on GitHub. It requires OAuth scope such as `user` or `read:org` to access this information. Use this tool to find out which organizations a user is part of and can manage.

parameters.name: page_number_to_fetch
parameters.description: Page number of the results to fetch for user organizations.

parameters.name: results_per_page
parameters.description: The number of organizations listed per page, up to a maximum of 100.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: ListUserProjects
tools.description:
Retrieve a list of GitHub projects for a specific user.

parameters.description: The GitHub username of the account whose projects are to be listed.

parameters.name: project_state
parameters.description: Specify the state of projects to return. Options are 'open', 'closed', or 'all'.

parameters.name: results_page_number
parameters.description: Specify the page number of the results to fetch when listing user projects.

parameters.name: results_per_page
parameters.description: The number of projects to display per page, up to a maximum of 100.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: ListUserReceivedPublicEvents
tools.description:
Retrieve public events received by a GitHub user.

This tool fetches a list of public events received by a specified GitHub user. It should be called when there is a need to understand the public activities involving the user.

parameters.name: github_user_handle
parameters.description: The GitHub handle for the user account whose public events are to be listed.

parameters.name: page_number
parameters.description: Specify the page number of the results you wish to fetch.

parameters.name: results_per_page
parameters.description: The number of results to return per page, with a maximum of 100.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: ListUserRepositories
tools.description:
Retrieve repositories accessible to the authenticated user.

This tool lists repositories that the authenticated user can access with explicit permissions like `:read`, `:write`, or `:admin`. It includes repositories owned by the user, those where they are collaborators, and those accessible through organization membership.

parameters.name: filter_repositories_before_timestamp
parameters.description: Only show repositories updated before the specified timestamp in ISO 8601 format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`.

parameters.name: repository_affiliation_filter
parameters.description: Specify affiliations for repositories to list. Options: `owner`, `collaborator`, `organization_member`. Provide as a comma-separated string.

parameters.name: repository_type
parameters.description: Limit results to repositories of the specified type: 'all', 'owner', 'public', 'private', or 'member'. Avoid using with 'visibility' or 'affiliation'.

parameters.name: repository_visibility
parameters.description: Limit results to repositories with the specified visibility: 'all', 'public', or 'private'.

parameters.name: results_page_number
parameters.description: Specify the page number of the results to fetch.

parameters.name: results_per_page
parameters.description: The maximum number of repositories to display per page. Accepts an integer up to 100.

parameters.name: sort_order
parameters.description: Specify the order to sort repositories. Use 'asc' for ascending or 'desc' for descending. Default is 'asc' for 'full_name' sort and 'desc' otherwise.

parameters.name: sort_property
parameters.description: Property by which to sort repositories, such as `created`, `updated`, `pushed`, or `full_name`.

parameters.name: updated_after_timestamp
parameters.description: Filter repositories updated after the specified ISO 8601 timestamp (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ).

tools.name: ListUsersWithBranchAccess

Retrieve users with push access to a protected branch on GitHub.

This tool should be called to obtain a list of users who have push access to a specific protected branch in a GitHub repository. It is applicable to both public and private repositories under various GitHub plans, including Free, Pro, Team, and Enterprise. Use this when you need to manage or review user permissions for branch access.

parameters.name: branch_name
parameters.description: The exact name of the branch to check for push access. Wildcard characters are not allowed.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the repository. It is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

Retrieve artifacts from a GitHub workflow run.

tools.name: ListWorkflowRunJobs
tools.description:
Retrieve jobs from a specific GitHub workflow run attempt.

This tool retrieves jobs for a specific workflow run attempt on GitHub. It is useful for users who need to monitor or analyze job details of a workflow run. Access to the repository is required, and permissions depend on whether the repository is public or private.

parameters.description: The account owner of the repository, not case sensitive.

parameters.description: The attempt number of the specific workflow run to retrieve jobs for. This is typically used to distinguish between multiple attempts of the same run.

tools.name: LockGithubIssue
tools.description:
Lock a GitHub issue or pull request conversation.

Use this tool to prevent further interactions with a specific GitHub issue or pull request by locking its conversation. It requires push access to the repository.

parameters.name: issue_number
parameters.description: The number that identifies the GitHub issue to lock.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the repository in which the issue or pull request exists. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. This name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: issue_lock_reason
parameters.description: The reason for locking the conversation. Acceptable values: 'off-topic', 'too heated', 'resolved', 'spam'.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: ManageEnterpriseSecurityFeature
tools.description:
Enable or disable a security feature for an enterprise.

Use this tool to enable or disable a specified security feature across all repositories within an enterprise. Requires administrative access and an access token with the `admin:enterprise` scope.

parameters.name: enterprise_identifier
parameters.description: The slug version of the enterprise name or the enterprise ID.

parameters.name: security_feature
parameters.description: Specify the security feature to enable or disable. Options: 'advanced_security', 'secret_scanning', 'secret_scanning_push_protection'.

parameters.name: set_enablement_status
parameters.description: Specify 'enable_all' to activate or 'disable_all' to deactivate the security feature for all repositories in the enterprise.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: ManageGithubEnvironmentSecret
tools.description:
Create or update an encrypted environment secret on GitHub.

This tool allows you to create or update an environment secret in a GitHub repository. It requires encryption of the secret value using LibSodium and authentication with a token that has the 'repo' scope. Ideal for automating secret management in deployment environments.

parameters.name: encrypted_secret_value
parameters.description: The secret value encrypted with LibSodium using a public key. Retrieve the key from the 'Get an environment public key' endpoint.

parameters.name: encryption_key_id
parameters.description: The identifier for the encryption key used to encrypt the secret. This is required to ensure the correct decryption of the secret on GitHub.

parameters.name: environment_name
parameters.description: The name of the environment in the GitHub repository where the secret will be created or updated.

parameters.name: repository_unique_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the GitHub repository where the secret will be managed.

parameters.name: secret_name
parameters.description: The name of the secret to be created or updated in the GitHub environment.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: ManageGithubRepoSecret
tools.description:
Create or update an encrypted GitHub repository secret.

Use this tool to create or update an encrypted secret for a GitHub repository. Authentication requires a token with the `repo` scope or `dependabot_secrets` permission. The secret must be encrypted using LibSodium.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the GitHub repository. This is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive. Specify the GitHub username or organization name.

parameters.name: secret_name
parameters.description: The name of the repository secret to create or update. Case insensitive.

parameters.name: encrypted_secret_value
parameters.description: The secret's value encrypted using LibSodium and a public key from the repository's public key endpoint.

parameters.name: encryption_key_id
parameters.description: The ID of the key used to encrypt the secret. This key is retrieved from GitHub's repository public key endpoint.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: ManageGithubThreadNotifications
tools.description:
Manage GitHub notifications for specific threads.

Use this tool to ignore future notifications for GitHub threads, or to subscribe to threads you aren't receiving notifications for. Ideal for managing notifications on watched repositories by ignoring or subscribing to specific threads.

parameters.name: notification_thread_id
parameters.description: The unique ID of the notification thread, as retrieved from the GitHub notifications API.

parameters.name: ignore_thread_notifications
parameters.description: Set to true to block all notifications from a thread. Use false to allow notifications.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: ManageOrgSecurityFeatures
tools.description:
Toggle security features for all repositories in an organization.

This tool is used to enable or disable a specified security feature across all repositories in a GitHub organization. It requires organization owner access or a security manager role, and a token with 'write:org' scope. GitHub Apps must have the 'organization_administration:write' permission.

parameters.name: organization_name
parameters.description: The name of the GitHub organization. This value is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: security_feature
parameters.description: Specifies the security feature to enable or disable. Options include: dependency_graph, dependabot_alerts, dependabot_security_updates, advanced_security, secret_scanning, secret_scanning_push_protection.

parameters.name: security_feature_action
parameters.description: Specifies whether to enable or disable the security feature for all organization repositories. Use 'enable_all' to activate and 'disable_all' to deactivate.

tools.name: MarkGithubNotificationsAsRead
tools.description:
Mark all GitHub notifications as read for the current user.

Use this tool to mark all notifications as 'read' in GitHub for the authenticated user. If there are too many notifications, the process may run asynchronously, and any remaining 'unread' notifications can be checked using a separate endpoint.

parameters.name: mark_notifications_as_read
parameters.description: A boolean flag to set notifications as read. True marks notifications as read.

parameters.name: notifications_last_read_timestamp
parameters.description: A timestamp marking the last time notifications were checked. Notifications updated since this time won't be marked as read. Use ISO 8601 format `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`. Leave empty to mark all as read.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: MarkGithubThreadAsRead
tools.description:
Mark a GitHub thread notification as read.

Use this tool to mark a GitHub notification thread as read. It mirrors the action of clicking a notification in the GitHub notification inbox.

parameters.name: notification_thread_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier for the GitHub notification thread to be marked as read. Obtain this from the `id` field when retrieving notifications.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: MarkRepoNotificationsAsRead
tools.description:
Mark all repository notifications as read for the user.

Use this tool to mark all notifications in a specified repository as read for the authenticated user. If there are too many notifications, the process may be completed asynchronously.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: last_checked_timestamp
parameters.description: Timestamp for last notification check in ISO 8601 format. Omitting marks all as read. Defaults to current time if omitted.

Merge a branch into a GitHub repository.

tools.name: MergeGithubPullRequest
tools.description:
Merge a pull request on GitHub.

This tool merges a specified pull request on GitHub for a given repository. It should be called when a user wants to merge changes from a pull request into the main branch. Notifications will be triggered, and users should be mindful of secondary rate limits.

parameters.description: The name of the repository. It is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_owner

parameters.description: Title for the automatic commit message after merging the pull request.

Move a column within a GitHub project board.

Move a project card to a different position.

Mute all future notifications for a GitHub thread.

Retrieve GitHub App installations for an organization.

tools.name: PromoteUserToSiteAdmin
tools.description:
Promote a user to site administrator on GitHub Enterprise.

Use this tool to elevate a user's role to site administrator within a GitHub Enterprise instance. Ensure the 'Content-Length' is set to zero when invoking this endpoint.

parameters.name: github_user_handle
parameters.description: The handle for the GitHub user account to be promoted to site administrator.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: ProvisionEnterpriseUser
tools.description:
Create a new SCIM enterprise user identity.

This tool creates an external identity for a new SCIM enterprise user. It's used for provisioning users in enterprises using SCIM before they can sign in through SAML. When converting an existing enterprise to use SCIM, the SCIM `userName` is utilized to match new users to existing enterprise users.

Note: Understanding the request schema is necessary to properly create
the stringified JSON input object for execution.

Modes:
- GET_REQUEST_SCHEMA: Returns the schema. Only call if you don't
  already have it. Do NOT call repeatedly if you already received
  the schema.
- EXECUTE: Performs the operation with the provided request body
  JSON.

If you need the schema, call with mode='get_request_schema' ONCE, then execute.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Operation mode: 'get_request_schema' returns the OpenAPI spec for the request body, 'execute' performs the actual operation

parameters.name: request_body
parameters.description: Stringified JSON representing the request body. Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'

Delete GitHub Actions caches by key for a repository.

Remove all labels from a GitHub issue.

Remove an authorized SSH key from GitHub Enterprise.

tools.name: RemoveBranchAccessRestriction
tools.description:
Remove access restrictions from a GitHub branch.

tools.name: RemoveBranchStatusCheckContexts
tools.description:
Remove status check contexts from a protected branch.

    Use this tool to delete status check contexts from a protected branch in a GitHub repository. This applies to various GitHub plans, allowing for flexible management of branch protections.

    Note: Understanding the request schema is necessary to properly create
    the stringified JSON input object for execution.

This operation also requires path parameters.

    Modes:
    - GET_REQUEST_SCHEMA: Returns the schema. Only call if you don't
      already have it. Do NOT call repeatedly if you already received
      the schema.
    - EXECUTE: Performs the operation with the provided request body

tools.name: UnsuspendGithubUser
tools.description:
Unsuspend a user on GitHub Enterprise.

This tool unsuspends a user on a GitHub Enterprise instance. It is disabled if the GitHub instance uses LDAP Sync with Active Directory LDAP servers, in which case it returns a `403` response. It should be called to restore access to a suspended user.

tools.name: UpdateBranchProtection
tools.description:
Update GitHub repository branch protection settings.

    Use this tool to update the protection settings of a branch in a GitHub repository. It requires admin or owner permissions. Note that specifying new arrays for users and teams will replace their previous values, and there is a limit of 100 items for users, apps, and teams combined.

    Note: Understanding the request schema is necessary to properly create
    the stringified JSON input object for execution.

This operation also requires path parameters.

    Modes:
    - GET_REQUEST_SCHEMA: Returns the schema. Only call if you don't
      already have it. Do NOT call repeatedly if you already received
      the schema.
    - EXECUTE: Performs the operation with the provided request body
      JSON.
      Note: You must also provide the required path parameters when executing.

    If you need the schema, call with mode='get_request_schema' ONCE, then execute.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Operation mode: 'get_request_schema' returns the OpenAPI spec for the request body, 'execute' performs the actual operation

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository on GitHub. The name is not case sensitive.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the GitHub repository, which is not case sensitive.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: branch_name
parameters.description: The name of the branch to update protection settings for. It cannot contain wildcard characters. For wildcard support, use the GraphQL API.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: request_body
parameters.description: Stringified JSON representing the request body. Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'

tools.name: UpdateGithubDependabotAlert
tools.description:
Update a GitHub Dependabot alert.

Use this tool to update a Dependabot alert in a GitHub repository. Requires an access token with `security_events` scope for private repositories or `public_repo` scope for public repositories. GitHub Apps need **Dependabot alerts** write permission.

parameters.name: alert_identifier
parameters.description: The unique number identifying a Dependabot alert in the repository. Find this at the end of the alert URL or in `number` fields from the `GET /repos/{owner}/{repo}/dependabot/alerts` response.

parameters.name: alert_state
parameters.description: Specifies the state of the Dependabot alert. Use 'dismissed' to dismiss an alert and 'open' to keep it open. A 'dismissed_reason' is required when setting to 'dismissed'.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the GitHub repository to update. It is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the GitHub repository. Not case sensitive.

parameters.name: dismissed_alert_comment
parameters.description: An optional comment to provide context when dismissing the alert.

parameters.name: dismissed_reason_for_alert
parameters.description: Reason for dismissing the alert. Required if `state` is set to `dismissed`. Allowed values: 'fix_started', 'inaccurate', 'no_bandwidth', 'not_used', 'tolerable_risk'.

dismissed_alert_comment.value: This alert is dismissed due to an inaccurate detection.

parameters.description: Operation mode: 'get_request_schema' returns the OpenAPI spec for the request body, 'execute' performs the actual operation

parameters.name: scim_user_identifier
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the SCIM user for updating their information.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: request_body
parameters.description: Stringified JSON representing the request body. Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'

tools.name: UpdatePullRequest
tools.description:
Update an existing pull request on GitHub.

Use this tool to update an existing pull request in a GitHub repository. This can be used when you need to modify the details of a pull request, such as its title, body, or state. Requires write access to the source branch or membership in the owning organization.

parameters.name: pull_request_number
parameters.description: The unique number identifying the pull request.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the repository to update the pull request in. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. This name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: maintainers_can_modify
parameters.description: Boolean value indicating whether maintainers can modify the pull request.

parameters.name: pull_request_body
parameters.description: Provide the updated content or description for the pull request.

parameters.name: pull_request_state
parameters.description: Specifies whether the pull request should be 'open' or 'closed'.

parameters.name: pull_request_title
parameters.description: The new title for the pull request. Use this to update the PR title.

parameters.name: target_base_branch
parameters.description: The name of the branch where changes should be pulled into. Must be an existing branch on the current repository.

pull_request_body.value: Updated description for the pull request.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: UpdatePullRequestBranch
tools.description:
Update a pull request branch with latest upstream changes.

Use this tool to merge the latest changes from the base branch into a pull request branch, ensuring it is up-to-date with upstream changes.

parameters.name: pull_request_number
parameters.description: The unique number that identifies the pull request to update.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: expected_head_sha
parameters.description: The most recent commit SHA of the pull request's HEAD. Must match the pull request's current HEAD to avoid a 422 error.

tools.name: UpdatePullRequestReview
tools.description:
Update the review summary comment on a pull request.

Use this tool to change the content of a review summary comment for a specific pull request on GitHub. This is useful for revising feedback or updating information provided in the review.

parameters.name: pull_request_number
parameters.description: The unique number that identifies the pull request.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the repository to update the review on. Case insensitive.

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The GitHub account owner of the repository, case insensitive.

parameters.name: review_body_text
parameters.description: The updated body text for the pull request review.

parameters.name: review_identifier
parameters.description: The unique integer ID of the review to be updated.

review_body_text.value: Updated feedback on the pull request. Please consider the changes suggested.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: UpdatePullRequestReviewProtection
tools.description:
Update pull request review protection settings for a branch.

    This tool allows updating the pull request review enforcement settings on a protected branch, requiring admin or owner permissions. It applies to branches in both public and private repositories with enabled branch protection settings.

    Note: Understanding the request schema is necessary to properly create
    the stringified JSON input object for execution.

This operation also requires path parameters.

    Modes:
    - GET_REQUEST_SCHEMA: Returns the schema. Only call if you don't
      already have it. Do NOT call repeatedly if you already received
      the schema.
    - EXECUTE: Performs the operation with the provided request body
      JSON.
      Note: You must also provide the required path parameters when executing.

    If you need the schema, call with mode='get_request_schema' ONCE, then execute.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Operation mode: 'get_request_schema' returns the OpenAPI spec for the request body, 'execute' performs the actual operation

parameters.name: repository_owner_name
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the repository. This value is not case sensitive.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: branch_name
parameters.description: The name of the branch to update. It must not contain wildcard characters. For wildcard support, use the GraphQL API.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: request_body
parameters.description: Stringified JSON representing the request body. Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'

tools.name: UpdateRepoActionsPermissions
tools.description:
Sets GitHub Actions permissions for a repository.

Use this tool to set the GitHub Actions permissions policy for a specific repository. Ideal when you need to enable or restrict actions in a repository under certain conditions. Ensure to authenticate with a token having the `repo` scope or a GitHub App with `administration` permissions.

parameters.name: enable_github_actions
parameters.description: Boolean flag indicating if GitHub Actions should be enabled on the repository. `True` enables, `False` disables.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: actions_permission_policy
parameters.description: Defines the policy for actions allowed to run: 'all', 'local_only', or 'selected'.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: UpdateRepoInvitation
tools.description:
Update a repository invitation on GitHub.

This tool updates the details of a repository invitation on GitHub. It should be called when you need to change the status or details of an invitation sent to a collaborator for a specific repository.

parameters.name: invitation_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the invitation to be updated. It must be an integer.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the repository to update the invitation for. It is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The GitHub username of the account owner of the repository. It's not case sensitive.

parameters.name: user_permissions
parameters.description: Specify the permission level for the user on the repository. Valid values are `read`, `write`, `maintain`, `triage`, and `admin`.

tools.name: UpdateRepoWebhookConfig
tools.description:
Update GitHub repository webhook configuration settings.

    This tool updates the webhook configuration for a specific GitHub repository. It is useful when you need to modify settings such as the payload URL, content type, or secret key of a webhook. Ensure you have appropriate permissions, such as the `write:repo_hook` or `repo` scope for access tokens, or `repository_hooks:write` for GitHub Apps.

    Note: Understanding the request schema is necessary to properly create
    the stringified JSON input object for execution.

This operation also requires path parameters.

    Modes:
    - GET_REQUEST_SCHEMA: Returns the schema. Only call if you don't
      already have it. Do NOT call repeatedly if you already received
      the schema.
    - EXECUTE: Performs the operation with the provided request body
      JSON.
      Note: You must also provide the required path parameters when executing.

    If you need the schema, call with mode='get_request_schema' ONCE, then execute.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Operation mode: 'get_request_schema' returns the OpenAPI spec for the request body, 'execute' performs the actual operation

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the repository. Not case sensitive.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: webhook_hook_id

tools.name: UpdateRunnerGroupEnterprise
tools.description:
Update the name and visibility of a self-hosted runner group in an enterprise.

Use this tool to update the name and visibility settings of a self-hosted runner group within a GitHub enterprise. This requires authentication with a token that has the 'manage_runners:enterprise' scope.

parameters.name: enterprise_identifier
parameters.description: The slug or ID of the enterprise to identify which enterprise the runner group belongs to.

parameters.name: runner_group_id
parameters.description: Unique identifier of the self-hosted runner group to update.

parameters.name: allow_public_repositories
parameters.description: Set to true if the runner group can be used by public repositories.

parameters.name: allowable_workflow_list
parameters.description: List of workflow names the runner group is allowed to run. Ignored unless `restricted_to_workflows` is set to `true`.

parameters.name: restrict_to_workflows
parameters.description: Set to true to restrict the runner group to only the workflows in the selected_workflows array.

parameters.name: runner_group_name
parameters.description: Name of the self-hosted runner group to be updated.

parameters.name: runner_group_visibility
parameters.description: Specifies whether the runner group is visible to all organizations or only selected ones. Valid values are 'selected' or 'all'.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: UpdateRunnerGroupSettings
tools.description:
Update name and visibility of a runner group in an organization.

Call this tool to change the name or visibility of a self-hosted runner group within a GitHub organization. Requires authentication with an access token that has the `admin:org` scope.

parameters.name: organization_name
parameters.description: The name of the organization. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: runner_group_id
parameters.description: Unique identifier of the self-hosted runner group being updated.

parameters.name: runner_group_name
parameters.description: The new name for the self-hosted runner group in the organization.

parameters.name: allow_public_repository_usage
parameters.description: Set to `true` to allow the runner group to be used by public repositories.

parameters.name: allowed_workflow_list
parameters.description: List of workflows the runner group can run. Ignored unless workflows are restricted.

parameters.name: restrict_runner_group_to_workflows
parameters.description: Set to `true` to restrict the runner group to running only the workflows specified in `selected_workflows`.

parameters.name: runner_group_visibility
parameters.description: Specifies the visibility of the runner group. Options: 'selected' for individual repositories, 'all' for all repositories, 'private' for all private repositories.

tools.name: UpdateSecretScanningAlertStatus
tools.description:
Update the status of a secret scanning alert on GitHub.

Use this tool to update the status of a secret scanning alert in a GitHub repository. Requires admin access and a personal access token with the `repo`, `security_events`, or `public_repo` scopes, or a GitHub App with `secret_scanning_alerts` write permission.

parameters.name: alert_identifier
parameters.description: The unique number identifying the secret scanning alert. Found in the alert URL or the response of `GET /repos/{owner}/{repo}/code-scanning/alerts`.

parameters.name: alert_state
parameters.description: Set the state of the secret scanning alert to 'open' or 'resolved'. 'Resolution' is required if set to 'resolved'.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the repository. Not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The GitHub username or organization name that owns the repository. It is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: alert_resolution_comment
parameters.description: An optional comment when closing an alert. Set to `null` if changing the alert state to `open`. Cannot be updated or deleted.

parameters.name: resolution_reason_for_secret_scanning_alert
parameters.description: Specifies the reason for resolving the alert when the state is set to 'resolved'. Possible values: 'None', 'false_positive', 'wont_fix', 'revoked', 'used_in_tests'.

tools.description:
Update security and scanning settings for enterprise repositories.

Use this tool to update the advanced security, secret scanning, and push protection settings for new repositories within an enterprise. Ensure you have admin access to the enterprise and an access token with the `admin:enterprise` scope.

parameters.description: The slug or ID of the enterprise. Accepts the enterprise's slug name or ID for identification.

parameters.name: enable_dependabot_alerts_for_new_repositories
parameters.description: Set to true to automatically enable Dependabot alerts for new repositories.

Update self-hosted runners in an organization's runner group.

This tool allows you to replace the list of self-hosted runners in a specified organization runner group. It requires an access token with the 'admin:org' scope. Use this when you need to manage or update the runners assigned to a runner group in your organization.

parameters.name: runner_group_id

Update self-hosted runners in an enterprise group.

tools.name: UpdateTeamDiscussion
tools.description:
Edits the title and body of a team discussion post.

Use this tool to update the title and content of a discussion in a GitHub team within an organization. Only the specified fields will be changed. Requires OAuth tokens with `write:discussion` scope.

parameters.name: discussion_id
parameters.description: The unique number identifying the discussion to be updated.

parameters.name: organization_name
parameters.description: The name of the organization. It is not case sensitive and uniquely identifies the organization on GitHub.

parameters.name: team_slug
parameters.description: Provide the slug (URL-friendly version) of the team's name. Case sensitivity is ignored.

parameters.name: discussion_body_text
parameters.description: The updated body text of the discussion post. Provide the new content you want for the discussion.

parameters.name: discussion_title
parameters.description: The new title for the discussion post. Only the provided title will be updated.

discussion_body_text.value: This is the updated content for our team discussion.

tools.name: UpdateTeamRepoPermissions
tools.description:
Manage team repository access and permissions.

Use this tool to add a repository to a team or update a team's permission on a repository within an organization. The caller must have admin access and visibility of the team. The repository should be owned by the organization. Returns a confirmation of the action taken.

parameters.name: organization_name
parameters.description: The name of the organization. This parameter is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the repository to be managed. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_owner_account
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: team_slug
parameters.description: The slug identifier of the team within the organization. It is not case-sensitive.

parameters.name: team_repo_permission
parameters.description: Permission to grant the team on this repository. Options: `pull`, `triage`, `push`, `maintain`, `admin`, or a custom role name defined by the organization. Defaults to team's current permission if unspecified.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: UploadSarifCodeScanningResults
tools.description:
Upload SARIF data to GitHub for code scanning results.

This tool uploads SARIF data from a code scanning analysis to a GitHub repository. Use appropriate access tokens for private or public repositories. Uploaded results appear in pull requests or the repository's security tab, depending on the reference used. SARIF data must be compressed and encoded before uploading.

parameters.name: base64_compressed_sarif_data
parameters.description: A Base64-encoded string of the SARIF file compressed using gzip. Ensure proper encoding before upload.

parameters.name: commit_sha
parameters.description: The SHA of the commit associated with the uploaded analysis. This links the SARIF data to a specific point in the repository's history.

parameters.name: git_reference
parameters.description: The full Git reference. Format: `refs/heads/<branch name>`, `refs/pull/<number>/merge`, or `refs/pull/<number>/head`.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the repository. It is not case sensitive and identifies where the SARIF data will be uploaded.

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository on GitHub, not case sensitive.

parameters.name: analysis_start_time
parameters.description: The timestamp when the analysis run began, in ISO 8601 format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`.

parameters.name: base_directory_for_analysis
parameters.description: The base directory used in the analysis as it appears in the SARIF file to map file paths correctly.

parameters.name: tool_name
parameters.description: Specifies the tool name used for generating the code scanning analysis. Defaults to 'API' if not provided. Supports filtering by tool GUID in alerts operations.

tools.name: UserFollowingList
tools.description:
Retrieve users followed by a specified GitHub user.

Call this tool to get a list of users that a specific GitHub user is following. It is useful for analyzing social connections or activity on GitHub.

parameters.name: github_user_handle
parameters.description: The GitHub username of the account whose followings you want to list.

parameters.name: result_page_number
parameters.description: The page number of the result set to retrieve. Use this to paginate results.

parameters.name: results_per_page
parameters.description: Specify the number of results to display per page. Maximum is 100.

documentationChunks.content:
<Callout type="warning">
All tools in this toolset require the following secret: `GIT_SERVER_URL`.
</Callout>

The `GIT_SERVER_URL` secret specifies the GitHub server URL. Use `https://api.github.com` for regular GitHub.com accounts, or your GitHub Enterprise server URL (e.g., `https://github.your-company.com/api/v3`) for GitHub Enterprise deployments.

- Learn how to [configure secrets](/guides/create-tools/tool-basics/create-tool-secrets).

<Callout type="info">
The GithubApi MCP Server uses the Auth Provider with id `arcade-github` to connect to users' GithubApi accounts. Configure the `arcade-github` auth provider to allow the MCP Server to access user accounts.
</Callout>

For detailed information on configuring the GitHub OAuth provider with Arcade, see the [GitHub Auth Provider documentation](/references/auth-providers/github).

summary:
Arcade Toolkit enables seamless interaction between LLMs and the GitHub API, allowing for efficient management and development of GitHub repositories. It provides developers with tools for automation, collaboration, and project management.

### Capabilities
- Automate GitHub actions and workflows for repositories.
- Manage branches, access permissions, and team collaborations.
- Handle repository secrets, issues, pull requests, and releases.
- Perform analytics on contributions, notifications, and security alerts.
- Integrate GitHub Apps and customize environment settings.

### OAuth
**Provider:** Github  
**Scopes:** None

### Secrets
The toolkit supports several types of secrets such as GitHub tokens, webhooks, and environment variables. For example, it allows the management of `GIT_SERVER_URL` securely.
